questions.text: You are declaring a patient brain-dead by using the Harvard criteria. All of the following parameters are checked for, except:
questions.solution:
Isoelectric EEG is included in Harvard criteria for brain death and not ECG.

Harvard criteria for brain death include:

  • Unreceptivity and unresponsiveness, demonstrated by an absent motor response to pain in all extremities.
  • No movements
  • Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  • Absence of elicitable reflexes
    • Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm.
    • Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.
  • Isoelectric EEG (confirmatory)

All these tests should be recorded. If there is no change after 24 hours, then the patient is declared brain dead.

Philadelphia protocol, Minnesota criteria are other criteria used to diagnose brain death.

Related Pearl: Harvard criteria for brain death

  • Unreceptivity and unresponsivity      
  • No movements    
  • Apnoea        
  • Absence of elicitable reflexes      
  • Isoelectric EEG (confirmatory)

questions.text: Kevorkian sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels.

  • It is characterised by fragmentation of blood column in the retinal vessels.
  • It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour.
  • It can be visualised by using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occuring in the eye

  • Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on sclera on either side of cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you noticed the following wound shown in the image below. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The given image is most likely suggestive of a stab wound because of the presence of fish-tails.

A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. The characteristics are

  • The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. 
  • The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. 
  • The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. 
  • The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface.
  • The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc.
  • The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt.
  • The blunt side may show small splits at each corner called fishtailing as shown below. 

 

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

 

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound. The image below shows a chop wound.

 
Option C- Lacerated wounds are characterised by the presence of swallow tails. The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails. Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown below.

questions.text: A dead body is found at a crime scene. On examining it, you notice that fixation of hypostasis has already occurred. What is the minimum time required for this finding to occur?
questions.solution:
Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death.

Purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependant parts of the body. It is called postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ suggilation/ vibices.

Timing of development of postmortem hypostasis:

  • Mottled patches – 1-3 hours following the death
  • Uniform area of staining – 3-6 hours following death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis – 6-12 hours

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered a blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present. A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

Ex:- Correct sequence of shots in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule applies to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: A man was found dead due to starvation.Which of the following findings will be seen on autopsy?
questions.solution:
In starvation, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. So bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder and gets distended.

Starvation:

  • The feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30–48 hours.
  • A person can survive for 10–12 days without food and water and for 6–8 weeks without food alone.
  • Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal.
  • Loss of 70–90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal.
  • There is a reduction in the weight and size of all organs except the brain.

Other features of starvation:

  • Dry, lustreless hair
  • Brittle nails 
  • Pale skin with edema around ankles
  • Loss of fat in subcutaneous tissue, in the omentum 
    (sparing of fat in female breast and orbit till later)
  • Atrophy of muscles and darkening due to lipochrome
  • The heart is atrophied with empty chambers
  • Pale and collapsed lung
  • Shrunken liver with necrosis
  • Tissue paper-like intestinal mucosa
  • Empty bladder

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the doctor because his family found him dressed as a woman. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act. However, he has no wish to undergo sex-change surgery. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetishistic transvestism.

It is a paraphilia characterized by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behavior involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. It is also called transvestic fetishism. It is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes.

Fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia whereas transvestism is a gender identity disorder. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality in fetishistic transvestism.

Option A: Transsexualism refers to an obsessional desire to become a member of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations. 

Option C: Frotteurism refers to a person who obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, or thighs, in public places). It is punishable under Section 290 IPC, with fine up to 200 Rs.

Option D: Gender dysphoria is a term that describes a sense of unease that a person has due to a mismatch between their biological sex and their gender identity. This sense of unease or dissatisfaction can lead to depression and anxiety and can have a harmful impact on daily life.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13
years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person

questions.text: Section 89 of the BNS deals with ____

choices.text: Death of the mother by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage
Concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.solution:
Section 89 (IPC 313) of BNS, states that if miscarriage is done without the consent of the woman, the punishment is life imprisonment.

Related sections:

  • Section 90 (IPC 314) of the BNS deals with the death of the mother caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage. (Option A)
  • Section 94(IPC 318) of BNS – deals with concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable. (Option B)
  • Section 92 (IPC 316) of BNS, states that an act leading to the death of a quick unborn child, done with the intention of preventing a child from being born alive, is guilty of culpable homicide and shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to ten years and shall also be liable to a fine. (Option C)
  • Section 93(IPC 317) of BNS, exposure or abandoning children are both punishable.
  • Section 94 (IPC 318) of BNS – concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.

Note- The phrase “quick with child” refers to advanced pregnancy when quickening can be felt.

questions.text: The ‘en masse’ removal of organs is a feature of which of the following autopsy techniques?
questions.solution:
The ‘en masse’ removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Rokitansky technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. Larynx and trachea are pulled downward, and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Ghon technique: Like the Rokitansky method, the Ghon method also employs the bloc method of removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal organs. However, the organs are removed 'en bloc', rather than with in-situ dissection. 
  • Letulle technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Which type of mechanical asphyxia does the image shown below represent?
questions.solution:
The type of mechanical asphyxia shown in the image is mugging.

Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. The image below shows strangulation by mugging.

 

Other options:

Option A: Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim, preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands.

Option B: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tying both ends of the stick with rope. Sometimes, two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, and rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the center of the neck across the windpipe, corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Option D: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

questions.text: Crown heel length of a 6 month old fetus would be:
questions.solution:
Crown heel length of a 6-month old fetus would be 30 cm.

According to the Rule of Hasse:

  • During the first five months of pregnancy the square root of the length gives the approx. age of the fetus in months.
  • During last five months the length in centimeters is divided by five gives the age in months.

Age of fetus in first five months = square root of the crown heel length in cm.

Age of the fetus during last 5 months of pregnancy = (Crown heel length in cm)/5

So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 i.e. 6 × 5 = 30 cm.

questions.text:
A female convict was allegedly tortured and raped by an investigating officer while in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be conducted?

BNS - Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Dowry death
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B- BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with any person who holds authority or a fiduciary role, is a public servant, manages a jail, remand home, custody facility, or women’s/children’s institution, and misuses their position or relationship of trust to induce or seduce a woman in their custody, charge, or present on the premises into having sexual intercourse with them (not amounting to rape), shall face imprisonment for a term of no less than five years, which may extend to ten years, along with a fine.

Option D- BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

questions.text: A girl who is _____  years old can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.
questions.solution:
A girl who is 13 years old, can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.

This is because the legal age for general physical examination is 12 years, for employment in a factory is 14 years and for consent for sexual intercourse is 18 years.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract, and are passed entirely in the faeces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.

Patients typically present with symptoms similar to tetanus such as

  • Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic. The anti-gravity muscles experience the most severe convulsions, causing the body to typically arch in hyperextension—a position called opisthotonus.
  • Risus sardonicus which results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back.
  • If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonus).
  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates and the patients should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

  • Mnemonic to remember signs and symptoms.
  • We know that CRAMPing of muscles leads to the exhaustive death of the person in strychnine poisoning. Therefore:
    • Convulsions
    • Reflex increased
    • Awful taste
    • Mind is conscious
    • Pupils dilated
  • Clonic-tonic convulsions
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus: fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Medico-legal implications:.

  • Although a poison, in relatively low doses can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a history of developmental delay is brought to a pediatric psychologist for evaluation after being involved in an incident where he caused significant damage to a neighbour's property. The child appears to lack an understanding of the consequences of his actions and exhibits signs of emotional immaturity. He will not be held guilty under which Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) section?
questions.solution:
In the given case of a 10-year-old child involved in property damage, he will not be held legally responsible under BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) Section 21 (IPC 83). This section specifies that a child aged 7 to 12, who demonstrates insufficient mental maturity, is not deemed criminally liable for their actions.

Given the child's developmental delays and lack of comprehension regarding the repercussions of his behaviour, he is protected from legal penalties or prosecution due to his inadequate mental maturity.

Other options:

Option A: BNS section 24(IPC 86) states that a person who commits an offence under voluntary intoxication is liable for the act.

Option B: BNS section 23(IPC 85) states that a person who commits an offence under involuntary intoxication is not liable for the act.

Option D: BNS section 22(IPC 84) states that an act of a person of an unsound mind (e.g. schizophrenia) is not liable for punishment or prosecution.

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 34-year-old tribal man who was under police custody for interrogation. On external examination, signs of third-degree torture were present. Which of the following incisions is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of custodial death. The incision that is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage is the elongated X- shaped incision.

An elongated X-shaped incision is used to dissect subcutaneous structures in the back of the body. It helps identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries when superficial imprints are faint. This type of incision is helpful in the reconstruction of events before death and is practiced in custodial death.

The image below shows the 'elongated X- shaped' incision:

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch and then run downwards as in the “I” shaped incision.  Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol. Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol. 

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis. It is a toxalbumin or phytotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis by affecting the ribosomal RNA polymerase. The seeds are flat to oval-shaped and have dark brown markings (shown below). It is a chemical warfare agent.

Option B: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius. The seeds are egg-shaped, scarlet in color, and have a black spot at one end (shown below). On ingestion, it causes gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tachycardia, and circulatory collapse. Injecting the active substance can mimic viperine snakebite. Rarely, it may lead to tetanic convulsions. 

The seeds of A. precatorius are decocted and mixed with datura, opium, onion, spirit, and water to form a paste. From this, small sharp needles called suis are made. They are used for hunting animals and even for homicide purposes.

Option C: Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

questions.text: Olive Green colored urine is seen in poisoning with:
questions.solution:
Olive green urine is seen in carbolic acid poisoning.

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Post mortem, the viscera should be preserved in a saturated salt solution. The skin has a reddish appearance with necrosis or ulceration. The body has a characteristic phenolic odor. The esophagus may look reddish and like parchment. The internal surface of the stomach may show prominent rugae with a leathery appearance, due to the opaque, coagulated, grey, or brown mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following poison can be found even in skeletonised remains of the body?
questions.solution:
Arsenic can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body.

Arsenic becomes fixed in the cancellous tissues of the long bones by conversion of phosphates to arsenates. The elimination of arsenic in this form is much slower and can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

Heavy metals such as lead, copper, mercury, including metalloids like arsenic and antimony, may be found in bones for a prolonged period in cases of chronic poisoning. They are also deposited in hair, nails, etc. For these reasons, when heavy metal poisoning is suspected, these specimens are collected in addition to the routine viscera and body fluids.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab inside his abdomen after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defenses by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata under section 300 Cr. P.C states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining a body discovered buried in soil, noting the decomposition stage suggests the body had been buried for approximately 8 days. If the body had been left exposed to air under similar environmental conditions, what would be the estimated time since death based on Casper's dictum?
questions.solution:
As the decomposition stage suggests the body had been buried for approximately 8 days, the equivalent decomposition in air would have taken place in 1/8th of that time.

Casper's rule or dictum states that a body decomposes in the air twice as fast as submerged in water, and eight times faster as buried in earth.

Therefore, the rate of decomposition is Air > Water > Soil. It is helpful in the estimation of time since death.  

Free access of air hastens putrefaction, partly because the air conveys organisms to the body. Putrefaction is rapid in a body buried in a damp, marshy or shallow grave without clothes or coffin, because the body is exposed to constant changes of temperature. Putrefaction is more rapid in warm, fresh water than in cold, salt water. It is more rapid in stagnant water than in running water.

Note: Forensic taphonomy is the study and interpretation of postmortem processes of human remains i.e. the history of a body following death.
The ratio of the time a body takes to decompose in air, water, and soil is 1:2:8. This means that the time taken by soil is greater than water and air. So, the correct order of time taken for decomposition is Soil > Water > Air.

questions.text: All of the following tests can be used to check the cessation of circulation, except:
questions.solution:
Winslow’s test is used to check the cessation of respiration while the Diaphanous test, Magnus’s test and Icard’s test are done to check the cessation of circulation.  

Winslow's test consists of placing a bowl of water on the chest and monitoring the movement on the water's surface.

Other tests for confirming cessation of breathing. are:

  • No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes
  • Feather test – No movement of a feather held in front of the nose
  • Mirror test – A mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture in breath.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

  • No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes
  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test) - Fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test) - Failure to show redness in the webspace between the fingers on transillumination from behind
  • Icard’s test - Fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration
  • Fingernail test - No blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is suggestive of a close-range shotgun blast injury to the knee. Birdshot pellets are visible within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

 

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy playing at the seashore drowned in the sea during high tide. Which of the following is seen in this type of drowning?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards sea water drowning. Hemoconcentration and hypernatremia is seen in this type of drowning.

Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and hypernatremia. This may lead to increased viscosity of blood and in turn lead to myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure and the RBCs get crenated.

Other options: 

Option B: Hemodilution and hyponatremia are seen in freshwater drowning. In freshwater drowning water enters the hypotonic alveoli, which is absorbed to blood easily and will result in hemodilution. This leads to swelling of RBCs, leading to lysis of RBCs causing hyperkalemia. This may lead to ventricular fibrillation and cerebral anoxia within 3-5 minutes and death.

Option A and C: Hemoconcentration with hyponatremia and hemodilution with hypernatremia are not seen in any form of drowning.

questions.text: The least common fingerprint pattern is _____________.
questions.solution:
Composite type (1-2%) is the least common fingerprint pattern.

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops - Most common type (60-70%)
  • Whorl - (25-30%)
  • Arch - (6-7%) They may be plain, tented, or exceptional. 
  • Composite forms (1 – 2%) - least common

The study of ridge patterns in the skin is Dactylography/ Galton-Henry system/ Dermatoglyphics. Fingerprints are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips.

Classification of fingerprints into different patterns is based on delta and core formation. Delta is a triangular arrangement formed where three separate ridge line flows come together. The core is the centermost portion of a ridge flow pattern. 

The number of delta and core for each pattern is given below.

Pattern  Delta  Core
Loop 1 1
Plain arch 0 0
Tented arch 1 delta at the base of the upthrust 0
Whorl 2 1

The image given below shows the delta and core in the different fingerprint patterns. For each type, the position of the core is marked with a green circle, and the delta is marked with a blue triangle.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pond fracture of the skull.

It appears as an indentation or a buckling-in of the skull, without actual fracture. It is more commonly seen in infants due to the elasticity of the bones. They are caused by an obstetric forceps blade or a blow from a blunt object. The dura mater is not torn and usually, the brain is not damaged.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following tests on live birth are based on the changes in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Wredin’s test is based on the changes in the middle ear.

Tests for live birth:

  • Wredin’s test – Before birth, the middle ear does not contain air. It only contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and the gelatinous substance is replaced by air. For this, the middle ear must be opened underwater by removing tegmen tympani. If an air bubble comes out, the test is said to be positive. This is not at all reliable.
  • Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30–40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35
  • Breslau’s second life test: Air enters the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. So if respiration has taken place, they float in water, otherwise, they sink.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine
